description: a(-1) = 2; for n >= 0, a(n) is the 10^n-th digit of e after the decimal point.
links: Alexander J. Yee, 500,000,000,000 Decimal Digits of E, March 7 2011 (numberworld.org).
example: 7 is the first digit of e after the decimal point, 4 is the 10th decimal digit of e, etc.
author: _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 30 2000
extensions: Four more terms from David Baugh, Apr 23 2004
a(11) from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 08 2012
a(12) is 7, per private communications today from Alexander J. Yee. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 08 2012
